title: R42746
content: The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) held elections for its Legislative Council (Legco) in 2012, with the newly elected members having the opportunity to consider political reforms for universal suffrage in 2017 and 2020. The selection of CY Leung as Chief Executive may impact Hong Kong's democracy prospects. The selection of CY Leung as Chief Executive in 2012 may impact Hong Kong's democracy prospects, as it appeared to be engineered by the Chinese government. The process of selecting the new Chief Executive and the results of the 2012 Legco elections could foretell problems for Hong Kong's path towards universal suffrage in 2017 and 2020. The 2012 election results in Hong Kong raised the risk of a political stalemate for democratic reforms. The selection of CY Leung as Chief Executive was seen as engineered by the Chinese government. The pro-democracy members won enough seats to block future election reforms they find unacceptable. This outcome is significant to Congress due to the Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992. The 2012 election results in Hong Kong may lead to a political stalemate for democratic reforms, as pro-democracy members gained enough seats to block unacceptable election reforms. This is important to Congress because of the Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992, which supports democratization in Hong Kong. The Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 supports democratization in Hong Kong, including the election of the Chief Executive and Legislative Council members by universal suffrage as outlined in the Basic Law. The conduct of the 2012 elections and potential political reforms reflect China's commitment to these principles. The Basic Law of Hong Kong, passed by China's National People's Congress in 1990, aims for universal suffrage in electing the Chief Executive and Legislative Council members. The 2012 elections and potential political reforms demonstrate China's commitment to these principles. Hong Kong may also serve as a testing ground for democratic reforms in Mainland China. Some scholars speculate that Hong Kong could be a testing ground for democratic reforms in Mainland China, signaling China's willingness for political changes. Conversely, opposition to democratic reforms in Hong Kong may indicate resistance to political changes in China. The potential for democratic reforms in Hong Kong could serve as a signal for China's willingness for political changes. Congress may consider supporting democracy in Hong Kong through funding and educational events to raise awareness. Congress may assess and support democracy in Hong Kong by appropriating funds, holding hearings, and raising awareness. The city's political system is executive-run, with the Chief Executive selected by an Election Committee. The Basic Law established an executive-run government in Hong Kong, led by the Chief Executive selected by an Election Committee. The committee was expanded in 2010, with most members appointed by organizations. The Election Committee in Hong Kong was expanded in 2010 to 1,200 members, with a nomination threshold of 150 members. The selection of the fourth Chief Executive was set for March 25, 2012, with three candidates successfully submitting nomination papers. Henry Tang Ying-yen, Hong Kong's Chief Secretary at the time, was one of the candidates. The date for the selection of Hong Kong's fourth Chief Executive was set for March 25, 2012, with three candidates successfully submitting nomination papers. Henry Tang Ying-yen, the presumed frontrunner, received support from 390 Election Committee members, while CY Leung, the dark horse candidate, obtained the support of 305 Election Committee members. Henry Tang Ying-yen, the presumed frontrunner for Chief Executive, received support from 390 Election Committee members. CY Leung, the dark horse candidate, obtained the support of 305 Election Committee members. Albert Ho Chun-yan, the pan-democrat candidate, had little chance of being selected and received backing from 188 members. Tang's bid faced problems before his formal nomination. Henry Tang Ying-yen received support from 390 Election Committee members for his Chief Executive nomination, while CY Leung obtained backing from 305 members. Albert Ho Chun-yan, the pan-democrat candidate, had little chance with 188 members supporting him. Tang's bid faced issues before his nomination, including admitting to an affair with his assistant and questions about his academic credentials. Before his formal nomination, Henry Tang Ying-yen faced issues such as admitting to an affair with his assistant and questions about his academic credentials. These problems persisted up to the selection day, with allegations of past affairs and questions about an unauthorized basement in one of his houses. Tang admitted to the illegal construction but denied knowledge of its extent. On February 13, 2012, Hong Kong media reported illegal construction work on Henry Tang's house, including an unauthorized basement with a private movie theater and wine cellar. Tang admitted to the basement but blamed his wife for its construction, leading to a loss of public support in favor of Leung. Tang's image suffered due to the illegal basement at his house, which he blamed on his wife. Public support shifted to Leung, with rumors of Chinese government support for Leung over Tang. The official vote by the Election Committee members took place on March 25, 2012. Leung won the election with 44% support, while Tang had 23% and Ho had 13%. Rumors circulated about Chinese government backing for Leung. The official vote occurred on March 25, 2012, with Leung receiving 689 votes to become the Chief Executive of Hong Kong on July 1, 2012. Leung won the election with 44% support, receiving 689 votes to become Hong Kong's fourth Chief Executive on July 1, 2012. His swearing-in ceremony was controversial as he took the oath in Mandarin Chinese, with Chinese President Hu Jintao presiding. On July 1, 2012, Leung was sworn in as Hong Kong's fourth Chief Executive in a controversial ceremony where he used Mandarin Chinese for the oath and inaugural speech, with Chinese President Hu Jintao in attendance. This raised concerns about his commitment to Hong Kong's autonomy. Leung's use of Mandarin during his inauguration with President Hu raised concerns about his commitment to Hong Kong's autonomy. The Legislative Council in Hong Kong has limited power, mainly introducing legislation not related to public expenditure or government structure. Legco can block legislation and has limited oversight of the government. The Legislative Council in Hong Kong, known as Legco, has the power to introduce legislation not related to public expenditure or government structure. It can also block legislation and has limited oversight of the Hong Kong government. Legco consists of members elected by geographical constituencies and functional constituencies, with only a small percentage of Hong Kong residents eligible to vote in the latter. In 1997, Legco in Hong Kong had two types of members - elected by geographical constituencies and chosen by functional constituencies. Less than 1 in 10 residents could vote in functional constituencies. In the 2012 election, 3.5 million voters could cast two votes for the 70-member Legco, one in geographical constituencies and another in functional or District Council constituencies. In the 2012 Legco election, Hong Kong's 3.5 million eligible voters could cast two votes for the city's 70-member Legislative Council. Voter turnout was 52.3%, higher than the 2008 election. The 2012 Legco election saw a higher voter turnout of 52.3% compared to 45.2% in 2008. The increase is attributed to public discontent with the Hong Kong government, particularly regarding the mandatory "national education" curriculum. Chief Executive CY Leung later made the teaching of this curriculum optional. In the 2008 election, voter turnout rose due to public discontent with the Hong Kong government, specifically regarding the mandatory "national education" curriculum. Despite Chief Executive CY Leung making the curriculum optional before the Legco election, concerns about government policies and attitudes remain high. The number of Legco seats increased from 60 to 70 under election reforms adopted in December 2010. Under election reforms adopted in December 2010, the number of Legco seats was increased from 60 to 70, with half elected by geographical constituencies and half by functional constituencies. The 35 geographical constituency seats were divided among five districts, proportionate to the number of eligible voters. The 35 functional constituencies seats were split between 30 allocated among the 28 "traditional" functional constituencies and 5 new District Council functional constituency seats. Under election reforms in December 2010, Legco seats increased from 60 to 70, split evenly between geographical and functional constituencies. Geographical seats divided among five districts based on eligible voters. Functional seats split between 30 traditional constituencies and 5 new District Council seats. Voters not eligible for traditional seats could vote in the new District Council constituency, dubbed "super seats" due to 3.2 million eligible voters. Under election reforms in December 2010, Legco seats increased from 60 to 70, split evenly between geographical and functional constituencies. Any Hong Kong voter not eligible for traditional functional constituencies could vote in the new District Council (second) functional constituency, known as "super seats" due to 3.2 million eligible voters. The functional constituencies in Hong Kong are a mix of economic and social groups, a legacy from British rule to ensure support in Legco.
